AccessionLocalUniqueIdentifier.Label: Transferred material identifier
AccessionLocalUniqueIdentifier.Description:
This element should hold the unique identifier of the accession as known and provided by the holding institute or collection. This means that the value should uniquely identify the accession in the source database.

This information will be used to identify accessions when receiving updates and will be returned in reports to allow the provider to match the original database records. This information is required.

This data element can be either a string or a number, or a series of sub-elements: in this last case these should be separated by a TAB character (“ ” or ASCII 9).
AccessionLocalUniqueIdentifier.Examples:
12487 A numeric identifier

WAB0020770 A string identifier

123 5175 A two-code identifier, in this case the identifier is made of two codes: you can separate the codes with a TAB character (for instance in systems tracking accessions by their selection and cross identifiers).

AccessionGlobalUniqueIdentifier.Label: Global unique identifier
AccessionGlobalUniqueIdentifier.Description:
This element represents the accession identifier known to the world, this identifier must be persistent. Provide the identifier if you have it, if you do not, the system will create a persistent identifier for you. Among the many standards we will use the LSID (Life Sciences Identifier) that will be composed as follows:

  • Authority: The FAO/WIEWS holding institute code (HoldingInstituteFAOCode).

  • Namespace: We will use the constant germplasm to indicate that the identifier applies to living material.

  • ObjectID: The catalogue number or accession number (AccessionNumber).

  • Version: The eventual sample identifier (SampleNumber).

Note that if any of the above information changes, the identifier will also change, this means that the above data elements should be persistent:

  • Authority: the FAO/WIEWS institutes database does not delete entries, when an institute changes or merges with another one, a new identifier will be assigned to the new entity and the old one will point to the new one.

  • ObjectID: If this information changes, it usually means that we are talking about another accession.

  • Version: In general, sample identifiers should not be re-used within an accession.
AccessionGlobalUniqueIdentifier.Examples:
urn:lsid:CIV033:WARDATOG:WAB0020770

A WARDA Oryza glaberrima collection accession

HoldingInstituteFAOCode.Label: Holding institute FAO code
HoldingInstituteFAOCode.Description:
The FAO/WIEWS code of the holding institute, all CGIAR institutes and most gene banks are covered by this resource.

Note that you do not need to provide this information, since all users must be registered and must provide information on the institute and collection holding their material.
HoldingInstituteFAOCode.Examples: PHL001 International Rice Research Institute (IRRI)

HoldingCollectionCode.Label: Holding institute collection code
HoldingCollectionCode.Description:
This code identifying the germplasm collection to which the accession belongs.

Note that you will provide the code the first time you will login into the warehouse, just ensure it doesn’t change all the time.

No restriction in format.
HoldingCollectionCode.Examples:
CIAT-CASSAVA The CIAT cassava collection.

ICARDAICPW The ICARDA primitive wheat collection.

AccessionNumber.Label: Accession number
AccessionNumber.Description:
This element represents the catalogue number of the accession within its holding institute. This code should uniquely identify the accessionwithin its holding institute, in cases in which such codes are re-used by different collections you should provide prefix or suffix it with an identifier that will make this code unique.

This code will be used when requesting material, so given this information, the collection curator should be able to uniquely identify the germplasm.

No restriction in format.
AccessionNumber.Examples:
TVSu-1027 An IITA accession (TGR-881B).

WAB0020770 A WARDA accession (TOG 10971).

SampleNumber.Label: Sample number
SampleNumber.Description: This value can be used whenever the germplasm refers to an accession sample; it is optional and should only be used if relevant.

AcquisitionSourceCode.Label: Collecting or acquisition source code
AcquisitionSourceCode.Description:
This coded value describes the origin of the accession. The coding scheme proposed can be used at 2 different levels of detail: either by using the general codes (in boldface) such as 10, 20, 30, 40 or by using the more specific codes such as 11, 12 etc.

  • 10 Wild habitat

    • 11 Forest, woodland

    • 12 Shrubland

    • 13 Grassland

    • 14 Desert, tundra

    • 15 Aquatic habitat

  • 20 Farm or cultivated habitat

    • 21 Field

    • 22 Orchard

    • 23 Backyard

    • 24 Fallow land

    • 25 Pasture

    • 26 Farm store

    • 27 Threshing floor

    • 28 Park

  • 30 Market or shop

  • 40 Institute, Experimental station, Research material

  • 50 Seed company

  • 60 Weedy, distributed or ruderal habitat

    • 61 Roadside

    • 62 Field margin

  • 99 Other (In case none of the above apply, describe in the next field)

AcquisitionSourceNotes.Label: Collecting or acquisition source description
AcquisitionSourceNotes.Description: This value should be used whenever AcquisitionSourceCode is not applicable: you should set the latter to 99 and provide here a description. This field can also be used to provide further information or comments.

BiologicalStatusCode.Label: Collecting or acquisition source code
BiologicalStatusCode.Description:
This coded value describes the sample biological status. The coding scheme proposed can be used at 3 different levels of detail: either by using the general codes (in boldface) such as 100, 200, 300, 400 or by using the more specific codes such as 110, 120 etc.

  • 100 Wild

    • 110 Natural

    • 120 Semi-natural

    • 130 Semi-natural/sown

  • 200 Weedy

  • 300 Traditional cultivar / Landrace

  • 400 Breeding / Research material

    • 410 Breeder's line

      • 411 Synthetic population

      • 412 Hybrid

      • 413 Founder stock - Base population

      • 414 Inbred line (parent of hybrid cultivar)

      • 415 Segregating population

    • 420 Mutant / Genetic Stock

  • 500 Advanced / Improved cultivar

  • 999 Other (In case none of the above apply, describe in the next field)

BiologicalStatusNotes.Label: Sample biological status notes
BiologicalStatusNotes.Description: This value should be used whenever BiologicalStatusCode is not applicable: you should set the latter to 999 and provide here a description. This field can also be used to provide further information or comments.

AcquisitionDate.Label: Acquisition date
AcquisitionDate.Description:
Date on which the accession entered the collection. The date will be interpreted as a string and can take the following formats:

  • YYYYMMDD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day.

  • YYYY-MM-DD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day.
AcquisitionDate.Examples:
19761205 December 5, 1976

1982-01-27 January 27th, 1982

GermplasmStorageTypeCode.Label: Type of germplasm storage
GermplasmStorageTypeCode.Description:
If germplasm is maintained under different types of storage, multiple choices are allowed (separated by a semicolon).

(Refer to FAO/IPGRI Gene bank Standards 1994 for details on storage type.)

  • 10 Seed collection

    • 11 Short term

    • 12 Medium term

    • 13 Long term

  • 20 Field collection

  • 30 In vitro collection (Slow growth)

  • 40 Cryopreserved collection

  • 99 Other (In case none of the above apply, describe in the next field).
GermplasmStorageTypeCode.Examples:
11 Short term

13;20 Long term and field collection

99 Other, describe in next field

GermplasmStorageTypeNotes.Label: Germplasm storage notes
GermplasmStorageTypeNotes.Description: This value should be used whenever GermplasmStorageCode is not applicable: you should set the latter to 99 and provide here a description. This field can also be used to provide further information or comments.

NumberOfConservedSamples.Label: Number of samples conserved
NumberOfConservedSamples.Description: This value should indicate the number of seeds, seedlings, budsticks, in vitro plants, etc. of an accession srored in the gene bank.

LastRegenerationDate.Label: Last regeneration date
LastRegenerationDate.Description:
Date in which the accession was last regenerated, the month and/or day can be omitted, it should be provided in one of the following formats:

  • YYYYMMDD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day. If the day is not known, it is possible to omit it (YYYYMM) and if the month is not known it also can be omitted (YYYY). You can also use dashes in place of missing month or day.

  • YYYY-MM-DD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day. If the day or month are missing, these can be replaced with zeros.

This date should possibly be derived from the planting date.
LastRegenerationDate.Examples:
1976-12-07 December 7th 1976

19761207 December 7th 1976

1976-12-00 December 1976

197612-- December 1976

197612 December 1976

1976-00-00 1976

1976---- 1976

19760000 1976

1976 1976

AccessionURL.Label: Accession URL
AccessionURL.Description: URL linking to additional data about the accession either in the holding gene bank or from another source.
AccessionURL.Examples:
http://genebank.org/accessions?id=12475
A fictitious example

InTrust.Label: In trust flag
InTrust.Description:
Provides the information, whether the accession is in trust or not.

If the information is not known, it should be omitted, rather than set to false.

Any of the following (case insensitive) codes apply:

  • 1; Y; Yes; true: Part of the MLS.

  • 0; N; No; false: Not part of the MLS.

Available.Label: Accession availability
Available.Description:
Whether the accession is available or not.

  • 1; Y; Yes; true: Available.

  • 0; N; No; false: Not available.

OtherAccessionIdentification.Label: Other identification associated with the accession
OtherAccessionIdentification.Description:
Any other identification (accession numbers) known to exist in other collections for this accession.

This data should be provided as a list of INSTCODE and ACCENUMB pairs, where INSTCODE refers to the FAO/WIEWS institute code of the holding institute and ACCENUMB refers to the accession number of the accession in the holding institute.

The format should be:

:;INSTCODE:ACCENUMB;INSTCODE:ACCENUMB; … INSTCODE:ACCENUMB

The first two characters (:;) represent respectively the character separating INSTCODE and ACCENUMB and the character separating pairs of INSTCODE and ACCENUMB. By default these are those in the example, in cases in which the accession number includes a colon or semicolon, you should provide in these first two tokens characters that are not used in the accession number or institute code.

The INSTCODE is optional, the ACCENUMB is required; the separator characters are required.

The INSTCODE token, if provided, must match the FAO/WIEWS institutes table.

When providing data
OtherAccessionIdentification.Examples:
:;NLD037:CGN00254;SWE002:NGB1912;:Bra2343;:PI 245820

.,NLD037.CGN00254,SWE002.NGB1912,.Bra2343,.A;45:AA

SafetyDuplicatesInstituteFAOCode.Label: Location of safety duplicates
SafetyDuplicatesInstituteFAOCode.Description: FAO Institute Code of the institute where a safety duplicate of the accession is maintained, if there are more than one, these codes may be separated by semicolon.
SafetyDuplicatesInstituteFAOCode.Examples:
NLD037;SWE002

NOR051

SafetyDuplicatesInstituteName.Label: Name of the safety duplicates holder
SafetyDuplicatesInstituteName.Description: The name of the institute that holds the safety duplicates, in the event that such institute is not among the FAO/WIEWS institutes table. If more than one, separate with semicolons.

CollectingDate.Label: Collecting date of sample
CollectingDate.Description:
Date in which the accession was collected. If the month or the day is not known, it is allowed to omit them, these are the allowed formats:

  • YYYYMMDD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day. If the day is not known, it is possible to omit it (YYYYMM) and if the month is not known it also can be omitted (YYYY).

  • YYYY-MM-DD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day. If the day or month is not known, these can be replaced with zeros.
CollectingDate.Examples:
1976-12-07 December 7th 1976

19761207 December 7th 1976

1976-12-00 December 1976

197612-- December 1976

197612 December 1976

1976-00-00 1976

1976---- 1976

19760000 1976

1976 1976

CollectingInstituteFAOCode.Label: Collecting institute FAO code
CollectingInstituteFAOCode.Description: FAO/WIEWS institute code of the institute that collected the sample, if more than one institute was involved you can separate the codes with a semicolon.
CollectingInstituteFAOCode.Examples:
COL003 Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical (CIAT)

PHL001;COL003 IRRI and CIAT.

CollectingInstituteName.Label: Name of the collecting institute
CollectingInstituteName.Description: The name of the institute that collected the sample, in the event that such institute is not among the FAO/WIEWS institutes table. If more than one, separate with semicolons.

Collectors.Label: List of collector names
Collectors.Description:
Names of the collectors, separated by semicolon.

Note that we might want to include these entries in the Cooperators table, in this case you would include here the cooperator codes. Suggestions are welcome.

CollectingMissionCode.Label: Collecting mission code
CollectingMissionCode.Description: The unique identifier of the collecting mission.

CollectingNumber.Label: Collecting number
CollectingNumber.Description: Original number assigned by the collector(s) of the sample, normally composed of the name or initials of the collector(s) followed by a number. This number is essential for identifying duplicates held in different collections.
CollectingNumber.Examples: FA90-110

BreedingDate.Label: Breeding date of sample
BreedingDate.Description:
Date in which the accession was bred. If the month or the day is not known, it is allowed to omit them, these are the allowed formats:

  • YYYYMMDD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day. If the day is not known, it is possible to omit it (YYYYMM) and if the month is not known it also can be omitted (YYYY).

  • YYYY-MM-DD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day. If the day or month is not known, these can be replaced with zeros.
BreedingDate.Examples:
1976-12-07 December 7th 1976

19761207 December 7th 1976

1976-12-00 December 1976

197612-- December 1976

197612 December 1976

1976-00-00 1976

1976---- 1976

19760000 1976

1976 1976

BreedingInstituteFAOCode.Label: Breeding institute FAO code
BreedingInstituteFAOCode.Description: FAO/WIEWS institute code of the institute that bred the sample, if more than one institute was involved you can separate the codes with a semicolon.
BreedingInstituteFAOCode.Examples:
COL003 Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical (CIAT)

PHL001;COL003 IRRI and CIAT.

BreedingInstituteName.Label: Breeding institute name
BreedingInstituteName.Description: The name of the institute that bred the sample, provide if the institute is not among those in the FAO/WIEWS table.

AncestralData.Label: Ancestral data
AncestralData.Description: Information about either pedigree or other description of ancestral information (i.e. parent variety in case of mutant or selection).
AncestralData.Examples:
Hanna/7*Atlas//Turk/8*Atlas

mutation found in Hanna

selection from Irene

cross involving amongst others Hanna and Irene

Breeders.Label: List of breeder names
Breeders.Description:
Names of the breeders, separated by semicolon.

Note that we might want to include these entries in the Cooperators table; in this case you would include here the cooperator codes. Suggestions are welcome.

DonorInstituteFAOCode.Label: Donor institute code
DonorInstituteFAOCode.Description: The FAO/WIEWS code of the donor institute, this information refers to material donated by another gene bank. This information is relevant only to material donated by another gene bank.
DonorInstituteFAOCode.Examples:
PHL001 International Rice Research Institute (IRRI)

COL003 Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical (CIAT)

DonorName.Label: Donor name
DonorName.Description: The name of the donor in the event it is not among the FAO/WIEWS institutes table.

DonorAccessionNumber.Label: Donor accession number
DonorAccessionNumber.Description: The number assigned to the accession by the donor in the donor gene bank. This information is relevant only to material donated by another gene bank.
DonorAccessionNumber.Examples: See AccessionNumber.

HoldingCollectionCode.Label: Holding institute collection code
HoldingCollectionCode.Description:
This code identifying the germplasm collection to which the accession belongs.

Note that you will provide the code the first time you will login into the warehouse, just ensure it doesn’t change all the time.

No restriction in format.
HoldingCollectionCode.Examples:
CIAT-CASSAVA The CIAT cassava collection.

ICARDAICPW The ICARDA primitive wheat collection.

HoldingCollectionName.Label: Holding institute collection name
HoldingCollectionName.Description:
The full name of the collection to which the accession belongs.

Note that you will provide the name.
HoldingCollectionName.Examples:
CIAT cassava collection

ICARDA primitive wheat collection

HoldingCollectionContact.Label: Holding institute collection focal point name
HoldingCollectionContact.Description: The full name of the person responsible for the collection.
HoldingCollectionContact.Examples: John Smith An imaginary example.

HoldingCollectionEmail.Label: Holding institute collection e-mail address
HoldingCollectionEmail.Description: The e-mail address used to communicate with the staff responsible of the collection.
HoldingCollectionEmail.Examples: j.smith@cgiar.org An imaginary example

HoldingCollectionAddress.Label: Holding institute collection mailing address
HoldingCollectionAddress.Description: The address used to communicate via mail with the staff responsible of the collection.

RequestingCollectionContact.Label: Focal point name for requesting material
RequestingCollectionContact.Description: The full name of the person responsible for material requests.
RequestingCollectionContact.Examples: John Smith An imaginary example.

RequestingCollectionEmail.Label: E-mail address used to request material
RequestingCollectionEmail.Description: The e-mail address used for requesting material.
RequestingCollectionEmail.Examples: j.smith@cgiar.org An imaginary example

HoldingCollectionProviderContact.Label: Data provider name
HoldingCollectionProviderContact.Description:
The full name of the person responsible for providing the collection data.

In general this will refer to the user providing data to SINGER.
HoldingCollectionProviderContact.Examples: John Smith An imaginary example.

HoldingCollectionProviderEmail.Label: Data provider e-mail
HoldingCollectionProviderEmail.Description:
The e-mail address of the collection data provider.

In general this will refer to the e-mail address of the person providing data to SINGER.
HoldingCollectionProviderEmail.Examples: j.smith@cgiar.org An imaginary example

AccessionLocalUniqueIdentifier.Label: Transferred material identifier
AccessionLocalUniqueIdentifier.Description: This code should uniquely identify the accession that is being transferred; see the AccessionLocalUniqueIdentifier descriptor in the Accession Identification section.

CooperatorCode.Label: Cooperator code
CooperatorCode.Description:
The unique identifier of the cooperator. This code should be used whenever referencing the cooperator.

If the cooperator refers to an institution (not a person affiliated to an institution) and that this institution belongs to the FAO/WIEWS institutes database, the code must be the FAO/WIEWS code.

If the cooperator is an individual, or an individual affiliated to an institution, it is the responsibility of the data provider to create this code, for this reason you should not use the FAO/WIEWS coding scheme (ISO 3166 3 character country code + a 4 digit number; e.g. USA1001).

When providing data on cooperators, and the record refers to an institution belonging to the FAO/WIEWS institutes database, you only need to provide the first two descriptors.
CooperatorCode.Examples:
COL003 CIAT (must match the FAO/WIEWS code)

123 A cooperator affiliated to CIAT

AAA An institution

TransferDate.Label: Material transfer date
TransferDate.Description:
The date in which the transfer occurred:

  • YYYYMMDD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day.

  • YYYY-MM-DD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day.
TransferDate.Examples:
1976-12-07 December 7th 1976

19761207 December 7th 1976

TransferSMTA.Label: Transfer SMTA type
TransferSMTA.Description:
The standard material transfer agreement type:

  • 1: Distributed as PGRFA.

  • 2: Distributed as PGRFA under development.

  • 3: Distributed as PGRFA under development with additional conditions.

CooperatorCode.Label: Cooperator code
CooperatorCode.Description:
The unique identifier of the cooperator. This code should be used whenever referencing the cooperator.

If the cooperator refers to an institution (not a person affiliated to an institution) and that this institution belongs to the FAO/WIEWS institutes database, the code must be the FAO/WIEWS code.

If the cooperator is an individual, or an individual affiliated to an institution, it is the responsibility of the data provider to create this code, for this reason you should not use the FAO/WIEWS coding scheme (ISO 3166 3 character country code + a 4 digit number; e.g. USA1001).

When providing data on cooperators, and the record refers to an institution belonging to the FAO/WIEWS institutes database, you only need to provide the first two descriptors.
CooperatorCode.Examples:
COL003 CIAT (must match the FAO/WIEWS code)

123 A cooperator affiliated to CIAT

AAA An institution

CooperatorType.Label: Cooperator type
CooperatorType.Description:
The type of entity:

  • 10: CGIAR centre.

  • 20: Commercial company.

  • 30: Farmer.

  • 40: Gene bank.

  • 50: National agricultural research centre.

  • 60: Non-governmental organisation.

  • 70: Regional organisation.

  • 80: University.

  • 90: Individual.

  • 100: Germplasm network.

  • 999: Other, describe in next field.

CooperatorTypeDescription.Label: Cooperator type description
CooperatorTypeDescription.Description: In the event that a cooperator does not belong to the above categories, place a description here.

CooperatorInstituteFAOCode.Label: Cooperator institute
CooperatorInstituteFAOCode.Description:
FAO/WIEWS code of the cooperator’s institute.

In the event that the cooperator’s institute is not among the FAO/WIEWS institutes, place the institute name in the next field.
CooperatorInstituteFAOCode.Examples: COL003 Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical (CIAT)

CooperatorInstituteName.Label: Cooperator institute name
CooperatorInstituteName.Description: The name of the cooperator’s institute, if it is not among the FAO/WIEWS institutes table.

CooperatorCountry.Label: Cooperator country
CooperatorCountry.Description: The ISO 3166 3 character country code of the country to which the cooperator belongs.

ValidCooperatorCode.Label: Valid cooperator code
ValidCooperatorCode.Description:
This field points to another cooperator: in the event that we collate cooperators, this field will be used to track cooperators that have changed institution.

For instance, John Smith has received material while working for CIMMYT, now he is working for ICARDA and he is going to receive material: rather than changing the original record, we create a new cooperator and we place in this field the new cooperator code.

For the moment you can ignore this field.

CollectingMissionCode.Label: Collecting mission code
CollectingMissionCode.Description: The unique identifier of the collecting mission.

CollectingMissionTitle.Label: Collecting mission title
CollectingMissionTitle.Description: The name or title of the collecting mission

CollectingMissionStart.Label: Collecting mission start date
CollectingMissionStart.Description:
Date in which the collecting mission started, these are the allowed formats:

  • YYYYMMDD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day. If the day is not known, it is possible to omit it (YYYYMM) and if the month is not known it also can be omitted (YYYY).

  • YYYY-MM-DD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day. If the day or month is not known, these can be replaced with zeros.
CollectingMissionStart.Examples:
1976-12-07 December 7th 1976

19761207 December 7th 1976

1976-12-00 December 1976

197612-- December 1976

197612 December 1976

1976-00-00 1976

1976---- 1976

19760000 1976

1976 1976

CollectingMissionEnd.Label: Collecting mission end date
CollectingMissionEnd.Description:
Date in which the collecting mission ended, these are the allowed formats:

  • YYYYMMDD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day. If the day is not known, it is possible to omit it (YYYYMM) and if the month is not known it also can be omitted (YYYY).

  • YYYY-MM-DD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day. If the day or month is not known, these can be replaced with zeros.
CollectingMissionEnd.Examples:
1976-12-07 December 7th 1976

19761207 December 7th 1976

1976-12-00 December 1976

197612-- December 1976

197612 December 1976

1976-00-00 1976

1976---- 1976

19760000 1976

1976 1976

CollectingMissionInstitutes.Label: List of collecting mission institute FAO codes
CollectingMissionInstitutes.Description: The FAO/WIEWS code of the institute(s) involved in the collecting mission, multiple entries should be separated by semicolon.
CollectingMissionInstitutes.Examples:
ITA303 IPGRI

ITA303;PHL001 IPGRI and IRRI

CollectingMissionCountries.Label: Collecting mission list of countries
CollectingMissionCountries.Description: The countries visited by the collecting mission, the data should be the ISO3166 3 character country code, and multiple entries should be separated by semicolon.
CollectingMissionCountries.Examples:
BRA Brazil

BRA;PER Brazil and Peru

CollectingMissionCollectors.Label: Collecting mission list of collector names
CollectingMissionCollectors.Description: The names of the collectors that participated in the mission, separated by semicolon.
CollectingMissionCollectors.Examples:
John Smith

John Smith (ICARDA); Jane Toll (IPGRI)

CollectingSiteCode.Label: Collecting site identifier
CollectingSiteCode.Description:
This code should uniquely identify the collecting site, this information should be provided if you manage the collecting sites as a separate unit in your database. If you do not manage sites as an individual entity, this information is optional.

Note that collecting and breeding sites in SINGER will be managed both as an individual unit, this means that it will be possible to retrieve from SINGER the list of sites referenced by your dataset, along with the site code assigned by SINGER.

CollectingSiteCountryCode.Label: Collecting site country code
CollectingSiteCountryCode.Description: ISO3166 3 character code of the country in which the sample was collected at the time. An extended country codes table will be provided, including countries in which accessions were collected in the past, but that do not exist any more (e.g. Yugoslavia, URSS).
CollectingSiteCountryCode.Examples:
COL Colombia

CSK Czechoslovakia

CollectingSiteAdmin1.Label: Collecting site primary administrative unit
CollectingSiteAdmin1.Description: The primary administrative unit of the collecting site, this could be the province.
CollectingSiteAdmin1.Examples: Castilla y León

CollectingSiteAdmin2.Label: Collecting site secondary administrative unit
CollectingSiteAdmin2.Description: The secondary administrative unit of the collecting site, this could be the department.
CollectingSiteAdmin2.Examples: Soria

CollectingSiteAdmin3.Label: Collecting site tertiary administrative unit
CollectingSiteAdmin3.Description: The tertiary administrative unit of the collecting site, this could be the municipality.
CollectingSiteAdmin3.Examples: Vinuesa

CollectingSiteLocation.Label: Location of collecting site
CollectingSiteLocation.Description: Location information below the tertiary administrative level that describes where the accession was collected. This might include the distance in kilometres and direction from the nearest town, village or map grid reference point.
CollectingSiteLocation.Examples:
7 km south of Curitiba in the state of Parana

Pico del Castillo_Santa Ines y Verdugal

CollectingSiteLatitude.Label: Latitude of collecting site
CollectingSiteLatitude.Description:
The coordinate can be provided either as degrees, minutes and seconds or as decimal degrees. It is important that you provide the original information and not, for instance, decimal degrees converted from degrees, minutes and seconds: missing seconds are an indication of the precision.

These are the accepted formats:

  • Decimal degrees: a floating point number such as what GPS devices return, positive numbers for the northern hemisphere and negative numbers for the southern one.

  • Degrees, minutes and seconds: the coordinate divided into degrees, minutes and decimal seconds:

    • DD°MM’SS.SSS”H: (standard Google Earth) where DD stands for degrees, MM for minutes, SS.SSS stands for decimal seconds and H for the hemisphere (N for north, S for south). Seconds and minutes, if not known, can be omitted, the other elements are required. The tokens that represent the symbols for degrees, minutes and seconds [°’”] can be replaced with a space.

    • DDMMSSH: (EURISCO standard) where DD stands for degrees, MM for minutes, SS stands for seconds and H for the hemisphere (N for north, S for south). Missing minutes and/or seconds should be replaced with dashes, as in the EURISCO standard, or simply omitted. Leading zeros for minutes and seconds are required.

Degrees should range between 0 to less than 90; minutes and seconds should range between 0 to less than 60.
CollectingSiteLatitude.Examples:
45.123456

45°32’27.4875”N

45 32 27.4875 N

453227N

45°32’S

45 32 S

4532--N

4532N

CollectingSiteLongitude.Label: Longitude of collecting site
CollectingSiteLongitude.Description:
The coordinate can be provided either as degrees, minutes and seconds or as decimal degrees. It is important that you provide the original information and not, for instance, decimal degrees converted from degrees, minutes and seconds: missing seconds are an indication of the precision.

These are the accepted formats:

  • Decimal degrees: a floating point number such as what GPS devices return, positive numbers for the eastern hemisphere and negative numbers for the western one.

  • Degrees, minutes and seconds: the coordinate divided into degrees, minutes and decimal seconds:

    • DDD°MM’SS.SSS”H: (standard Google Earth) where DDD stands for degrees, MM for minutes, SS.SSS stands for decimal seconds and H for the hemisphere (E for east, W for west). Seconds and minutes, if not known, can be omitted, the other elements are required. The tokens that represent the symbols for degrees, minutes and seconds [°’”] can be replaced with a space.

    • DDDMMSSH: (EURISCO standard) where DDD stands for degrees, MM for minutes, SS stands for seconds and H for the hemisphere (E for east, W for west). Missing minutes and/or seconds should be replaced with dashes, as in the EURISCO standard, or simply omitted. Leading zeros for minutes and seconds are required.

Degrees should range between 0 to less than 180; minutes and seconds should range between 0 to less than 60.
CollectingSiteLongitude.Examples:
76.123456

76°32’27.4875”E

76 32 27.4875 E

0763227E

763227E

120°32’W

120 32 W

12032—W

12032W

CollectingSiteGeodeticDatum.Label: Collecting site coordinates geodetic datum
CollectingSiteGeodeticDatum.Description:
The geodetic datum to which the latitude and longitude refer. A table is provided with a series of known datums.

The standard datum is WGS84, for instance, Google maps, are in this datum: rather than providing an enumerated table, you should do the following:

  • Provide WGS84 as the value if you know that the coordinates are in this datum.

  • Provide the datum name if you know the datum and it is not WGS84.

  • Omit the information if you don’t know the datum.
CollectingSiteGeodeticDatum.Examples:
WGS84

WGS-72

ARC-1950 mean, Clarke 1880

Canada Mean (NAD27), Clarke 1866

CollectingSiteCoordinatesPrecision.Label: Coordinates precision
CollectingSiteCoordinatesPrecision.Description:
The precision of the coordinates expressed in kilometers. This information is necessary to determine the exact area of the coordinates. When providing coordinates in degrees, minutes and seconds, this could be automatically calculated; when the coordinates were determined on a map, this information should be provided.

Note that the referenced DarwinCore term is in meters, while this term is in kilometres.

CollectingSiteCoordinatesSource.Label: Coordinates source
CollectingSiteCoordinatesSource.Description:
Source of the coordinates, a proposed enumeration:

  • 1: GPS device.

  • 2: Map

  • 3: Digital gazetteer.

  • 9: Other, describe in CollectingSiteCoordinatesSourceNotes.
CollectingSiteCoordinatesSource.Feedback: This may not be an exhaustive list: feedback is welcome to complete it.

CollectingSiteCoordinatesSourceNotes.Label: Coordinates source notes
CollectingSiteCoordinatesSourceNotes.Description: Use this field to place a description of the coordinates source if the previous field is 9.

CollectingSiteCoordinatesSourceReference.Label: Coordinates source reference
CollectingSiteCoordinatesSourceReference.Description: Reference to specific map or other source for the coordinates.

CollectingSiteElevation.Term (DarwinCore):
MinimumElevationInMeters
MaximumElevationInMeters
CollectingSiteElevation.Label: Elevation of collecting site
CollectingSiteElevation.Description: Elevation of collecting site expressed in meters above sea level. Negative values are allowed.
CollectingSiteElevation.Examples:
763

-40

CollectingSiteElevationPrecision.Label: Precision of collecting site elevation
CollectingSiteElevationPrecision.Description: Precision of the collecting site information in meters.

BreedingSiteCode.Label: Breeding site identifier
BreedingSiteCode.Description:
This code should uniquely identify the breeding site, this information should be provided if you manage the breeding sites as a separate unit in your database. If you do not manage sites as an individual entity, this information is optional.

Note that collecting and breeding sites in SINGER will be managed both as an individual unit, this means that it will be possible to retrieve from SINGER the list of sites referenced by your dataset, along with the site code assigned by SINGER.

BreedingSiteAdmin2.Label: Breeding site secondary administrative unit
BreedingSiteAdmin2.Examples: Soria

TaxonCode.Label: Taxon code
TaxonCode.Description:
The unique identifier of the taxon in SINGER.

This information will be available once all SINGER taxa will be collated, then you can download this information and when referencing a known taxon you will only need to provide this code.

When the system will allow matching taxa to standard taxonomic nomenclatures, you will follow an iterative process in which matched taxa will change their code to the referenced standard taxonomy nomenclature entry.

Genus.Label: Genus name
Genus.Description: Genus name for taxon, in Latin. Initial uppercase letter required.
Genus.Examples: Allium

Species.Scope: Required (if the species has been determined)
Species.Label: Species name
Species.Description: Specific epithet portion of the scientific name, in Latin, in lowercase letters. Following abbreviation is allowed: ‘sp.’
Species.Examples: paniculatum

SpeciesAuthority.Label: Species authority
SpeciesAuthority.Examples: Maiden & Betche

InfraspecificEpithet.Label: Infraspecies epithet
InfraspecificEpithet.Description:
Subtaxa can be used to store any additional taxonomic identifier, in Latin. Following abbreviations are allowed: ‘subsp.’

(for subspecies); ‘convar.’ (for convariety); ‘var.’ (for variety); ‘f.’ (for form).
InfraspecificEpithet.Examples: subsp. fuscum

InfraspecificAuthority.Label: Infraspecies authority
InfraspecificAuthority.Description: The subtaxa authority at the most detailed taxonomic level.
InfraspecificAuthority.Examples: (Waldst. et Kit.) Arc.

ScientificName.Label: Full taxon name
ScientificName.Description: The full taxonomic name, this, along with the other information will be used to match taxa against standards.
ScientificName.Examples: Pisum sativum var.-gr. medullare Alef.

TaxonRank.Label: Taxon rank
TaxonRank.Description:
The rank of the taxon, we include here the ranks including and below genus; fewer will apply, but we include all for completeness:


  • genus: Genus, gen.

  • nothogenus: ngen. or nothogen.

  • nothosubgenus: nsubgen. or nothosubg.

  • subgenus: subg.

  • nothosectio: nsect. or nothosect.

  • sectio: Section or sect.

  • nothosubsectio: nsubsect. or nothosubsect.

  • subsectio: or subsect.

  • nothoseries: nser. or nothoser.

  • series: Series or ser.

  • subseries: Subseries or subser.

  • nothosubseries: nsubser. or nothosubser.

  • species: Species. or spec.

  • nothospecies: nspec. or nothosp.

  • nothosubspecies: nssp. or nothosubsp.

  • subspecies: Subspecies. or subsp. ssp.

  • varietas: Variety or var.

  • nothomorph: nm.

  • nothovarietas: nvar. or nothovar.

  • variety-group: var.-gr.

  • nothosubvarietas: nsubvar. or nothosubvar.

  • subvarietas: Subvariety or subvar.

  • forma: Forma or f.

  • nothoforma: nf. or nothof.

  • nothosubforma: nsubf. or nothosubf.

  • subforma: Subforma or subf.

  • cultivar: Cultivar or cv.

  • cultivar-group: cultivar-group or cv.-gr.
TaxonRank.Examples: subvarietas

AccessionName.Label: Name
AccessionName.Description: This data element contains the name associated with the accession.
AccessionName.Examples:
SIK 47-378-4 Accession name

wheat Crop name

zuti osmak Vernacular name

AccessionNameType.Label: Name type
AccessionNameType.Description:
The type of name, here is the proposed enumeration:

  • LOC: Local name of landrace/traditional cultivar in area where collected. Should not be confused with local name of the crop – see code CROP below.

  • CUL: Cultivar (released variety) name.

  • BRD: Breeder’s designation assigned by the breeder(s). Frequently referred to as line name or line number.

  • CROP: Name of crop.

  • SEL: Selection identifier. Frequently used to indicate relatively simple selection from diverse accession, e.g. selecting resistant plant from the landrace.

  • NURS: Nursery entry.

  • GS: Genetic stock designation.

  • NAME: Could be used for names created in the collection/gene bank by merging two or more names and/or numbers to achieve uniqueness of ‘accession names’ in collection.
    Example: Name ‘ABYSSINIAN-BAR CI1237’ is clearly concatenation of 3 parts:
    (a) ‘ABYSSINIAN’ –- local name indicating landrace from Abyssinia (Ethiopia)
    (b) ‘BAR’ –- barley (crop)
    (c) ‘CI1237’ – Accession number in USDA collection (should be CIho 1237)

AccessionNameContext.Label: Name context
AccessionNameContext.Description:
Scope/context the name was created or assigned. This data element extends/gives precision to NameType as shown below:

  • ACC: Institute where accession number was originally assigned.
    There are known cases where there are two accession numbers assigned to the same accession. This may indicate the temporal change in procedures/rules of assigning accession numbers.
    Examples:
    (1) CI and PI numbers assigned to cereal accessions in USDA collection; CI numbers were assigned in the past, later on PI numbering system was introduced and many accessions have double accession numbers.
    (2) Crop numbers and gene bank (crop-independent accession numbers) assigned to accessions in ICARDA gene bank; discussion similar to (1) above.

  • COL: Collector/Collecting mission who assigned the collector’s number.
    (1) Some collectors assign consecutive/unique collection numbers during their carrier. NameContext can thus hold the reference to the collector. Frequently, however, numbering of collected samples starts from scratch for particular collecting mission. In such cases, NameContex should refer to mission rather than individual collector.
    (2) In case of joint mission of several institutes, sometimes people from each institute assign their own collecting numbers to same accessions. Such numbers are synonymous and the field PrefNameType gives the possibility to flag ‘Y’ the numbers, which are considered now as the main ones.

  • LOC: Country/region/local community where the name of landrace/traditional cultivar was created.

  • CUL: Country where cultivar was registered.

  • BRD: Organization/breeding program where the material was bred.

  • CROP: Area where crop name is used.

  • TAX: Taxonomic classification.

  • SEL: Organization where the material was bred/selected. Applies to simple selections, otherwise BRD is used.

  • NURS: Organization which run the nursery in question.

This data element may be difficult to establish precisely for many NameType, e.g. LOC, CUL, TAX, etc. In case of (understandable) difficulty, leave the field NameContext blank. For other fields like ACC, BRD, SEL, NURS, knowing the NameContext is essential and every effort should be made to provide it

AccessionNameLanguage.Label: Language of the name
AccessionNameLanguage.Description:
Language in which the name was created, the information should be provided in the form of a IANA Subtag Language Registry code (RFC 5646 Language Subtag Registry).

This code is composed of several sub-tags of which the first one represents the 2 or 3 character ISO 639 language code: this sub-tag is required.
AccessionNameLanguage.Examples:
de German

en English

sr Serbian

sr-Cyrl Serbian written using the Cyrillic script

sr-Latn Serbian written using the Latin script

zh-cmn-Hans-CN Chinese, Mandarin, Simplified script, as used in China

sr-Latn-RS Serbian written using the Latin script as used in Serbia

AccessionNameDate.Label: Date assigned
AccessionNameDate.Description:
The date in which the name was assigned:

  • YYYYMMDD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day. If the day is not known, it is possible to omit it (YYYYMM) and if the month is not known it also can be omitted (YYYY).

  • YYYY-MM-DD: Where YYYY stands for the year, MM for the month and DD for the day. If the day or month is not known, these can be replaced with zeros.

This information could be useful to track naming in time.
AccessionNameDate.Examples:
1976-12-07 December 7th 1976

19761207 December 7th 1976

1976-12-00 December 1976

197612 December 1976

1976-00-00 1976

1976 1976

AccessionMainName.Label: Preferred name flag
AccessionMainName.Description:
Flag to indicate which Name should be considered as main/principal one. Only one name should have code ‘Y’; all others should be flagged ‘N’.

Any of the following (case insensitive) codes apply:

  • 1; Y; Yes; true: Main name.

  • 0; N; No; false: Not main name.

AccessionPreferredName.Label: Multiple preferred names flag
AccessionPreferredName.Description:
This field allows taking care of multiple names of a single type. Let us consider a few cases (some are mentioned above):

  1. If during the collecting missions, different collectors assigned different collector numbers, all these numbers can be recorded with type COL (and with different NameContext indicating collector(s)).

  2. Some gene banks/collections have more than one ‘accession number’ for accessions. For example, ICARDA has old accession numbers (which were unique for crops) and new accession numbers (which are unique across crops); USDA now uses PI numbers which are unique for all genetic resources in National System but there are also historical CI numbers which were unique for different collections of cereals. All such numbers can still be usefully logged in with ACC type.

  3. Variants of translated/transcribed/transliterated names. Frequently all variants are valid and thus can all be added (this concerns mainly names of CUL and LOC types)

  4. Some names, particularly of CUL and LOC types, have abbreviated variants, (e.g. KDML105 is a common abbreviation for Khao Dawk Mali 105) and these can also be accommodated.

Flag [Y] in field PrefNameType would indicate which of multiple name (of the same type) is preferred

Any of the following (case insensitive) codes apply:

  • 1; Y; Yes; true: Preferred name.

  • 0; N; No; false: Not preferred name.

AccessionNameLocalUse.Label: Use of name in data provider collection
AccessionNameLocalUse.Description:
Code showing how the Name is treated/interpreted in the (local) collection of data provider:

A – Accession number

D – Donor number/identifier

N – Accession name

C – Collection/collector’s number

O – Other name/number

The purpose of this field is to accommodate data provider’s view and to provide the linkage to the local documentation system
